author: kevaundray
content:
Added a golang version of proto danksharding using gnark-crypto and based off of the new cryptography API in 3038 (still changing).

One question I have for client devs; now that your code essentially does no cryptography except compute version hashes. Is it more convenient to pass the blob as `[]byte` instead of `[][]byte` ? Same question re commitments

author: kevaundray
content:
Link to the two possible APIs : 

API_1 : <https://github.com/crate-crypto/go-proto-danksharding-crypto/blob/master/api.go#L29>

API_2 : <https://github.com/crate-crypto/go-proto-danksharding-crypto/blob/master/alt_api.go#L10>

The APIs were quickly hashed together as I'm mostly trying to get feedback on what input structure is desired

author: terencechain
content: I dont really have a strong preference here but `[][]byte` is slighly nicer for us. The differences between the two isn't that much so I'll let someone else decide ðŸ™‚

author: kevaundray
content: Ahh thanks for the input ðŸ™‚ , I guess it depends on what you are going to do with it outside of using it with those cryptography functions

author: kevaundray
content:
----

I also added a check to make sure that blobs were canonical (this now stops someone from committing to two blobs where the byte representation differs by the modulus). 

I ran a quick benchmark on my laptop and this adds ~1ms to the algorithm per polynomial when done sequentially, so the cost over many threads will probably be insignificant.

The tracking issue is here for discussion : <https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/issues/3057>
